tags.name: Users
tags.description: Create, login, and manage users and their notes

tags.name: Wiki
tags.description: A series of Routes for Language, Alphabet, Country, and other Geo-socio-political data.

parameters.name: dam_id
parameters.description: Setting this Param will limit the results to the bible matching the `bible_id` or `dam_id` provided.

parameters.name: media
parameters.description: Setting this Param will filter the results by the media type provided. The Possible Media Types are available via the `v4_bible_filesets.types` route

parameters.name: language
parameters.description: Setting this field equal to an iso639-3 code will filter the resulting filesets to match only those containing that language.

parameters.name: full_word
parameters.description: Setting this param will filter results to match only those Languages where a name exists. Spanish bibles could be found by setting `full_word` to `Spanish` but We recommend using the Iso Code filter `language` instead of this option where possible as it provides a greater level of precision.

parameters.name: language_family_code
parameters.description: Setting this field equal to an iso639-3 code will filter the resulting filesets to match only those containing that language and it's dialects.

parameters.name: updated
parameters.description: Setting this param will filter results only created after a specific date

parameters.name: organization_id
parameters.description: Setting this param will filter results to those were created by the organization specified.

parameters.name: sort_by
parameters.description: Setting this param will filter results by

parameters.name: country
parameters.description: Setting this param will filter results by the Country code given. `AL` would return a couple different languages. Albanian Sign Language, Albanian, ect.

parameters.name: bucket
parameters.description: Filter by the providing organization's bucket name. Setting this param will filter results to be only those provided through a specific `bucket_id`

parameters.name: filter_by_fileset
parameters.description: This when set to false will return records for all Bibles regardless of whether or not it contains a fileset_id

error.message: No Authentication Provided or invalid Key

get.summary: Get extended Metadata for a single Bible

alphabet.name: Latin
alphabet.description:
The Latin script (also called the Roman script) is the most widely used writing system in the world, being the script of the English language, spoken by over 300,000,000 people worldwide. It is also the script used for writing a number of Romance, Germanic, Baltic and non-Indo-European languages, as well as the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA).

The script was derived from the Western variant of the Greek alphabet. The earliest extant inscription, an engraved brooch now in the ‘Museo Nazionale Preistorico Etnografico Luigi Pigorini’ in Rome, has been dated to the 7th century BC. The script developed slowly over the next thousand years, and by the 4th century AD many of the modern forms had been developed, and writing had settled into a consistent left to right direction. The Latin script was disseminated throughout western, northern and central Europe and the Baltic countries along with the Christian religion. However it was not until the colonization of the Americas, Australia, and parts of Asia, Africa and the Pacific that the script began to spread outside of Europe, carried by the English, Spanish, Portuguese, French, and Dutch languages.

As the script spread around the world, a number of language-specific amendments were made in order to accurately represent the sounds of various languages. These included ligatures, for example the German esszett ß, and a number of diacritics. Some languages also adapted the alphabet by the addition of entirely new letters, such as eth Ðð used in Faroese and Icelandic or epsilon Ɛɛ used in many Niger-Congo orthographies.

The Latin script is bicameral; it is written using both upper- and lower-case letters. It is written horizontally from left to right. Each letter sits on the baseline, with some letters having descenders hanging below the baseline, and some having ascenders protruding beyond the x-height. The script also uses a set of punctuation, which is almost entirely consistent across European languages. Exceptions to this include different syles of quotation marks (“ ” and « »), the Greek question mark, which is identical to the semicolon in many other languages (;), and the Spanish inverted question/exclamation marks (¿ and ¡).

Digits from 0-9 are used. These can be combined to represent larger numbers.

data.name: King James Version
data.description:
In 1604, King James I of England authorized that a new translation of the Bible into English be started. It was finished in 1611, just 85 years after the first translation of the New Testament into English appeared (Tyndale, 1526). The Authorized Version, or King James Version, quickly became the standard for English-speaking Protestants. Its flowing language and prose rhythm has had a profound influence on the literature of the past 400 years. The KJV is public domain in the United States.

From Wikipedia: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Version)
The King James Version (KJV), also known as the King James Bible (KJB) or simply the Authorized Version (AV), is an English translation of the Christian Bible for the Church of England begun in 1604 and completed in 1611. The books of the King James Version include the 39 books of the Old Testament, an intertestamental section containing 14 books of the Apocrypha (most of which correspond to books in the Vulgate Deuterocanon adhered to by Roman Catholics), and the 27 books of the New Testament.

It was first printed by the King's Printer Robert Barker and was the third translation into English approved by the English Church authorities. The first had been the Great Bible, commissioned in the reign of King Henry VIII (1535), and the second had been the Bishops' Bible of 1568. In January 1604, James VI and I convened the Hampton Court Conference, where a new English version was conceived in response to the problems of the earlier translations perceived by the Puritans, a faction of the Church of England. The translation is noted for its "majesty of style", and has been described as one of the most important books in English culture and a driving force in the shaping of the English-speaking world.

James gave the translators instructions intended to ensure that the new version would conform to the ecclesiology and reflect the episcopal structure of the Church of England and its belief in an ordained clergy. The translation was done by 47 scholars, all of whom were members of the Church of England. In common with most other translations of the period, the New Testament was translated from Greek, the Old Testament from Hebrew and Aramaic, and the Apocrypha from Greek and Latin. In the Book of Common Prayer (1662), the text of the Authorized Version replaced the text of the Great Bible for Epistle and Gospel readings (but not for the Psalter, which substantially retained Coverdale's Great Bible version) and as such was authorised by Act of Parliament.

By the first half of the 18th century, the Authorized Version had become effectively unchallenged as the English translation used in Anglican and English Protestant churches, except for the Psalms and some short passages in the Book of Common Prayer of the Church of England. Over the course of the 18th century, the Authorized Version supplanted the Latin Vulgate as the standard version of scripture for English-speaking scholars. With the development of stereotype printing at the beginning of the 19th century, this version of the Bible became the most widely printed book in history, almost all such printings presenting the standard text of 1769 extensively re-edited by Benjamin Blayney at Oxford, and nearly always omitting the books of the Apocrypha. Today the unqualified title "King James Version" usually indicates that this Oxford standard text is meant.

Outside of the United Kingdom, the KJV is in the public domain. Within the United Kingdom, the rights to the KJV are vested in the Crown.
data.vdescription:
In 1604, King James I of England authorized that a new translation of the Bible into English be started. It was finished in 1611, just 85 years after the first translation of the New Testament into English appeared (Tyndale, 1526). The Authorized Version, or King James Version, quickly became the standard for English-speaking Protestants. Its flowing language and prose rhythm has had a profound influence on the literature of the past 400 years. The KJV is public domain in the United States.

From Wikipedia: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Version)
The King James Version (KJV), also known as the King James Bible (KJB) or simply the Authorized Version (AV), is an English translation of the Christian Bible for the Church of England begun in 1604 and completed in 1611. The books of the King James Version include the 39 books of the Old Testament, an intertestamental section containing 14 books of the Apocrypha (most of which correspond to books in the Vulgate Deuterocanon adhered to by Roman Catholics), and the 27 books of the New Testament.

It was first printed by the King's Printer Robert Barker and was the third translation into English approved by the English Church authorities. The first had been the Great Bible, commissioned in the reign of King Henry VIII (1535), and the second had been the Bishops' Bible of 1568. In January 1604, James VI and I convened the Hampton Court Conference, where a new English version was conceived in response to the problems of the earlier translations perceived by the Puritans, a faction of the Church of England. The translation is noted for its "majesty of style", and has been described as one of the most important books in English culture and a driving force in the shaping of the English-speaking world.

James gave the translators instructions intended to ensure that the new version would conform to the ecclesiology and reflect the episcopal structure of the Church of England and its belief in an ordained clergy. The translation was done by 47 scholars, all of whom were members of the Church of England. In common with most other translations of the period, the New Testament was translated from Greek, the Old Testament from Hebrew and Aramaic, and the Apocrypha from Greek and Latin. In the Book of Common Prayer (1662), the text of the Authorized Version replaced the text of the Great Bible for Epistle and Gospel readings (but not for the Psalter, which substantially retained Coverdale's Great Bible version) and as such was authorised by Act of Parliament.

By the first half of the 18th century, the Authorized Version had become effectively unchallenged as the English translation used in Anglican and English Protestant churches, except for the Psalms and some short passages in the Book of Common Prayer of the Church of England. Over the course of the 18th century, the Authorized Version supplanted the Latin Vulgate as the standard version of scripture for English-speaking scholars. With the development of stereotype printing at the beginning of the 19th century, this version of the Bible became the most widely printed book in history, almost all such printings presenting the standard text of 1769 extensively re-edited by Benjamin Blayney at Oxford, and nearly always omitting the books of the Apocrypha. Today the unqualified title "King James Version" usually indicates that this Oxford standard text is meant.

Outside of the United Kingdom, the KJV is in the public domain. Within the United Kingdom, the rights to the KJV are vested in the Crown.

parameters.name: book_id
parameters.description: This when set to a valid USFM Book ID this param will filter records by that book ID. For a complete set of book_ids see the `v4_bible.allBooks` route

parameters.name: dam_id
parameters.description: This when set to a valid Bible_ID this param will filter records by that Bible ID. For a complete set of bible_ids see the `v4_bible.all` route

parameters.name: book_id
parameters.description: This when set to a valid USFM Book ID this param will filter records by that book ID. For a complete set of book_ids see the `v4_bible.allBooks` route

parameters.name: chapter_id
parameters.description: When set to a chapter number this param will filter records by that chapter number. This number will between 1 & 150.

parameters.name: verse_start
parameters.description: When set to a verse number this param will filter records to those starting at and after that verse_number.

parameters.name: verse_end
parameters.description: When set to a verse number this param will filter records to those starting at or before that verse_number.

parameters.name: bucket_id
parameters.description: Specifies the bucket for the resource desired. This field is associated with a particular `fileset_id` in the `v4_bible_filesets.show` & `v4_bible_filesets.index` routes and the complete list of buckets are available via the bucket

data.verse_text: فِي ٱلْبَدْءِ خَلَقَ ٱللهُ ٱلسَّمَاوَاتِ وَٱلْأَرْضَ.
وَكَانَتِ ٱلْأَرْضُ خَرِبَةً وَخَالِيَةً، وَعَلَى وَجْهِ ٱلْغَمْرِ ظُلْمَةٌ، وَرُوحُ ٱللهِ يَرِفُّ عَلَى وَجْهِ ٱلْمِيَاهِ.

get.summary: A list of Media types delivered by the API
Get a list of permissions for all filesets.

200.description: A set of Access details for a specific fileset

post.summary: To add a new set of permissions to the API.

200.description: You must either be a super_admin or be the owner of the fileset to be authorized for this route.

404.description: No fileset has been found for the provided hash_id

error.message: No fileset has been found for the provided hash_id

put.summary: To update an existing set of permissions to the API.

200.description: You must either be a admin or be the owner of the fileset to be authorized for this route.

get.summary: Download either a full zipped audio Bible or a selection

parameters.name: bucket_id
parameters.description: This param states which bucket the resource should be downloaded from.

get.summary: An rss ready format for the audio filesets

200.description: An podcastable ready format for the audio filesets

get.summary: Get generalized data for books of the Bible

200.description: An array of all the Books in the Bible

get.description: Returns a list of countries with generalized data

parameters.name: membership
parameters.description: The slug value for an organization, if provided. The results will be filtered by members of that organization.

get.description: This route delivers non-scripture resources: commentaries, books, and other films. It may be filtered by language via the `iso` code and organization by the `organization_id`. The results are paginated by default and the pagination length may be controlled via the `limit` variable.

parameters.name: iso
parameters.description: The iso 639-3 code for the language you wish to filter by

parameters.name: organization_id
parameters.description: The integer or slug value for an organization

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The number of results to return with each pagination

get.summary: Get a single resource by it's ID

put.summary: Update a single resource by it's ID.
put.description: This route will update a single resource by it's ID but in order to do so you must either belong to the organization that owns the resource or have `archivist` level permissions. Some resources are updated via API. Changes made to this type of resource will be overwritten on the next update. These resources are indentified by a `source_id`

post.description: This route will create a single resource but order to do so you must either belong to an organization or have `archivist` level permissions. Please do not create a resource for which your organization already has a connected API as that will introduce duplicates into the system. To see a list of connected APIs, please see the `connections` route.

delete.description: This route will delete a single resource but order to do so you must either belong to the owning organization or have `archivist` level permissions.

get.summary: Get notes for a specific user

post.summary: Create a new note for a user

put.summary: Edit an existing note for a user

id.description: An incrementing ID for the resources

iso.description: An iso 639-3 code to identify the primary language of the resource

eng.title: The Story of the Home for Bible Translators

id.description: An incrementing ID for the languages resources

iso.description: An iso code for the languages

v.name: v
v.description: The Version Number of the API

key.name: key
key.description: The API key that's been generated for you.

pretty.name: pretty
pretty.description: A sugar param, simply will format the call for human eyes

version.name: key
version.description: The API key that's been generated for you.

reply.name: reply
reply.description: Specifies the response type requested by the caller. Default is json.

callback.name: callback
callback.description: If unused the results are as before. If set to true, the results will be prepended with the array of calling arguments used. This does mean that the results will be one layer deeper as the results will be an array where the first element is the array of input arguments and the second element will be the results as normally returned.

dam_id.name: dam_id
dam_id.description: To get the location directory and asset file basename for a specific volume.
